div1.head: Interview of Jefferson Randolph Kean, by Philip Showalter Hench, June 5, 1946

list.head: QUESTIONING OF GENERAL KEAN BY DR. HENCH

item.p:
Q. #65 In your letter of September 17, 1940 you said “........Be-
cause Agramonte had come to me and complained that I had done him a
great injustice in a formal Senate document” I inserted a statement
of his over the signature of the Surgeon General.

Did Agramonte actually visit you about this so-called injustice,
or just write to you.

list.item:
ANSWER: I am sure he just wrote to me. I have found a letter from
Agramonte in which he takes up this matter and discusses it with a great
deal of feeling. The statement was from the Surgeon General to sup-
port a bill to give pensions to the widows of Dr. Lazear and Dr. Carroll
and was written in 1908. There is some ground for complaint of the
statement which I prepared for the Surgeon General and it went out in
his name, but not as much as Agramonte seems to think. In one place a
paper is alluded to as written by members of the Board, but his name is
left out. I imagine that this was an accidental omission by the sten-
ographer. It is true, however, that I did an injustice to Agramonte
by stating that he had nothing to do with the mosquito work after La-
zear's death. I got that statement from Dr. Carroll. Agramonte
states that he took Lazear's cultures and jars of infected mosquitoes
down to his laboratory - I think military hospital No. 1 - and kept
them there until Camp Lazear was established. Agramonte did not seem
to realize that the Surgeon General memorandum had special reference to
the work of the two men whose widows were asking for the pension, so
special emphasis was laid on the services of these two men. (Agramonte's
letter is dated July 3, 1908).

Q. #66: When was your painting which is hanging in Havana painted -
in 1909 as one of your letters says, or 1911 as one of my notes says?

ANSWER: In 1911, painted by to be looked up my diary VII p. 78
says that crayon portraits of Gov. Magoon, Dr Findlay and me were unveiled in the sa
sala of the Junta Nacional March 7, 1908- The oil portraits were doubtless made later

file in
name

Q. #67: I have told you that Mrs. Rojas told me that Major Reed
used to visit Camp Lazear, and then sit on their front porch. He liked
it there very much, and expressed his liking of it, and one day her
husband suggested that if Major Reed really did want to come back to
Cuba to live, he would give him a part of the Finca of San José to
build a little home and go there and retire. What is your impression of
that?

ANSWER Reed had a lovely place in Pennsylvania where he went on vacations
and visits. I do not know why he would want to live in Cuba in view of
this, I am sure. Reed was probably making conversation with the Rojas
family.

Q. #68: On page 1 of our interview of May 8, 1941 there is mention of
a request of Carroll to have a check for $950.00. Don't you think that
should have been #150.00?
ANSWER Certainly - $150.00

Q. #69 In the old book which mentioned the expenses of Camp Lazear,
there is a check for $150.00 for Kissinger, and later on the same day
another check for $50.00 for Kissinger. Do you remember what that was
for?

item.p:
ANSWER My recollection is that the $150.00 was to get Kissinger a
gold watch and chain to be presented to him by the Chief Surgeon as a
mark of appreciation for his submitting himself to the yellow fever ex-
periments
- 3 -
The check was, I think, endorsed by Kissinger.

Why was it not made out to Carroll instead of Kissinger if Carroll
was going to buy the watch?
expenses

I do not know just why this was. I always mentioned those exper-
iences to Reed, and it is possible I gave the check to Reed. I have no
recollection of Carroll entering into it at all.
What was the additional $50.00?

That was the balance of the $200.00 which was a gratuity for men who
had the yellow fever.
You told me before that Kissinger came back and asked for it.

Kissinger had expressed a desire to me for the balance of the money,
and so I gave him a check for it, apparently on the same day. The check
was drawn on the same day.

list.item:
Q. #70: This morning in the Army Medical Museum I saw in a cabinet
the small cloth container which Mrs. Reed presented to the Museum in
which, according to Mrs. Reed, all of the gold pieces given to the vol-
unteers who got yellow fever were held. Did he give the gold pieces, or
did you? Perhaps Mrs. Reed's note is in error. The checks were drawn
by you in the name of the men who received the money. Where did the
gold pieces come in if you gave the men checks?

ANSWER: The only gold pieces that I have any recollection of I drew
myself from the bank and took out to one of the early Spanish volunteers -
Antonio Benigno. My recollection is that I drew the money, and I re-
call his delight at receiving the great gold pieces (seventen $20.00
American gold pieces), and the nurses told me that he spent the whole
day playing with the gold pieces. One of the nurses, I was told,
made him a little bag to hold them. That is the only bag for gold pieces
of which I have any knowledge. What the other bag is for I do not know.

Q. #71 Do you know whether you or Dr. Reed cashed any of the other
checks and converted them in gold pieces and presented the volunteers
with gold rather than check?

item.p:
ANSWER: I did not give gold pieces to any other of the volunteers.
Whether Major Reed did or not, I do not know.

These checks made out by you in the name of the volunteers, were they
given directly to the volunteers, or did they countersign them and you
cashed them?

Most of them were made out to the volunteers and presented to Reed.
It is possible that he had the volunteer countersign the check, and he
had the pleasure of handing the money to the volunteer.

list.item:
Q. #72: On page 1 of our interview of May 8, 1941 you mentioned that
Lazear on June 1st pointed out to you the difference between the male
and female mosquitoes. What kind of mosquitoes?

ANSWER: My impression is the stegomyia, afterwards identified as
the yellow fever mosquito.

Q. #73: Do you think that at the time Lazear was interested in the
stegomyia even then as the cause of yellow fever in view of the fact that
you were visiting a yellow fever house and he pointed these mosquitoes
out to you?

ANSWER: I think so; it looks like it. In the light of subsequent
events I would think that even then he suspected that these mosquitoes
were the cause of yellow fever.

REMINISCENCE: In our conversation about the Starks on Monday night I
failed to mention an act of kindness and courage of Mrs. Stark's that
made a deep impression on me. When Major Edmunds, who lived
- 5 -
with his wife and two children in the house on General Lee St. in Que-
mados which I had formerly lived in, when he died of yellow fever and
his wife had come down with it, Mrs. Stark had the two children brought
to her and took care of them with her children although we all believed
at that time that yellow fever was a highly contagious disease.

item.p:
Dr. Hench: I visited Mrs. Stark yesterday and asked her about this
story. She laughed and said that she remembered the incident as follows:
She was in her house one evening and heard you (General Kean) and her
husband conversing in the next room. She overheard one of you say “
what shall we do with the little girl”. You kept talking about the
problem at hand, and she interrupted you and asked you “what is wrong,
what is worrying you”? You then told her about the serious illness of
Major Edmunds who was apparently dying and that his wife was also sick,
and that the little girl was alone except for the Cuban housemaid. She
immediately said “bring her over here”, and it appears that either you
or her husband hesitated about bringing the child from the yellow fever
house to her house, whereupon she said “let's go after her right away”,
whereupon you and her husband, and Mrs. Stark went over to Major Edmund's
house, and the little girl went in the room where her father lay dying,
and was allowed only to take out her tooth brush, the rest of her cloth-
ing she had to leave as they were in the room where her father was dying.
It was Mrs. Stark's recollection that herthe child's father died later that evening.
(General Kean's recollection is that the girl was 8 or 10 years old). It
is Mrs. Stark's recollection when Major Edmunds died, Mrs. Edmunds was
removed from the house and cared for in the yellow fever huts. Mrs.
Stark had to make elaborate arrangements so that the little girl would
not notice the funeral procession the next day when the Major was buried.
- 6 -
They were not prepared to tell the child, they preferred to have the
mother tell her. Later when Mrs. Edmunds recovered the child of course
went back with her mother. 'It was Mrs. Stark's impression that the
little Edmunds boy was not in Havana at the time.

Mrs. Stark told me the following anecdote about her two young sons
who were then about four years of age. One day one of these two boys
got in Major Reed's room - the end room in the bachelors' quarters. In
this room Reed happened to have some tubes or vials of black vomit.
Reed came into the room and found the two boys sitting sheepishly on the
floor with the black vomit all over their little white suits and the
vials broken. He grabbed them, one under each arm, and hurried them to
the hospital. He got in touch with their father and they were thoroughly
scrubbed with a disinfectant solution. Nothing was said to Mrs. Stark.
Later that evening the Stark's Cuban nurse told the two boys to get ready
to take their bath. They objected because they had already had a bath
in the afternoon. The mammy said something like this: “nonsense, when
did you have a bath”. They replied Reed had given them a bath at the
hospital. The nurse then said “don't be so foolish, why would he give
you a bath”? “Go along with you and take your bath”. Mrs. Stark knew
nothing about this for ten days. Dr. Stark took their temperature for
ten days, and when there was no danger Mrs. Stark was told.

I have also heard another story. These two boys mischievouslyy
swiped some postmortem specimens from Dr. Carroll's laboratory and held
him up for a bribe before they would give them back. Mrs. Stark did not
remember this story. She did not know whether these two stories were in
a sense the same story told in a different way, or whether they were two
different occurrences. She admitted her boys were mischievous enough
to have many things happen to them. Do you recall these two incidents,
or do you remember any similar episode?

What I remember is the second episode; that they got a bottle with
some pathological material in it from Carroll's room. They crawled
The floor slanted somewhat & Carroll couldn't go in after
them
under the floor of the bachelors' quarters. They would not surrender
the material until Carroll agreed to buy them some candy.
Would he keep material in his room? (Dr. Hench)
Apparently he did. (Gen. Kean)

list.item:
Q. 74: What was the name of Menocal of whom you often spoke, and who
was he?
ANSWER: Francisco E. Menocal, Commissioner of Immigration.

Q. 75: In regard to Question 11 on page 2 of our interview of May
8, 1941, did you hear that Carroll was upset about Lazear having put the
mosquito on him from Carroll himself or do you only know of it from
Hemmeter's book?
ANSWER: My impression is that I heard Carroll say it.

Q. 76: Can you tell me any more details about your visit to Dr. Reed
with Blossom when he was dying? You mentioned that you visited him about 8 P.M. November 24
Blossom was only in the room two minutes and burst in tears and ran out.
You stated that you were distressed that she could not control herself as
Reed had been anxious to see her. You went out and talked to Blossom
and asked her to come back in, but she said she could not. You then went
back in Reed's room and made up the excuse that she was made sick by the
odor from the wound. You were in the room only about ten minutes and Mrs
Reed was at home in her apartment. Did Do you remember any other con-
versation with Reed except his remark about the Colonelcy? He said he
was leaving so little. Do you remember?

item.p:
ANSWER: I think that he said that when he was going under the anes-
thetic.

Did he expect to die when he went under the anesthetic, or was that
the remark of any man who was having an operation?
My impression is that it was when he went under the operation.
Do you remember anything else he said, or that you talked about?
No, I do not.

list.item: Q. #77: In what building in IndianaIndianapolis iswas the Preliminary Note read?
ANSWER: Ravenal could tell you that.
Q. #78: What was the Army's reaction to Reed's work?

item.p: ANSWER: They accepted it promptly.
What was the reaction of non-medical officers?
I do not know.

General Lee was devoted to me, and he took me aside and said
“do not tie yourself up to this theory of Reed's about mosquitoes. I
am older than you are, and if they are disproved I am sure it will in-
jure your professional standing if you should be too enthusiastic about
it.” I told General Lee there was nothing I would rather risk my
reputation on than the proof of this theory.

list.item: Q. 79 In what connection did he say this and when?

item.p:
ANSWER: It was in the Fall 1900 when I was getting mosquito orders out.
He was a little uneasy about the proof of the theory as far as I was
concerned - it was about October or November 1900.

General Lee was the Commanding General, of the 7th Army Corps
until the end of December 1898. Then he was made the Commanding General
of the military department of Havana and then Pinar del Rio was added;
they discontinued Pinar del Rio as a separate department and gave him
both; then later they divided all Cuba into two departments and he was
given western Cuba.

list.item: Q #80: What was the reaction of the town physicians in Marianao?

ANSWER: Angelés was the only one I knew and he was always friendly.
We consulted them about yellow fever, but I think they probably thought
that we were a little snooty because we thought we knew their job better
than they.

Q. #81: What was the reaction of the women folks when the yellow
fever epidemic began in the Spring of 1900. Did they have a feeling of
quiet fear or were they panicky?

ANSWER: I think everybody had some fear and uneasiness about it ex-
cept General Fitzhugh Lee, but there was never any panic.
Q. #82: When the yellow fever began did you send your wives away?

item.p:
ANSWER: The officers were encouraged to send their wives and families
away. It made things easier for the Medical Department. Looking after
a case of yellow fever was a terrible thing as the facilities were not
good.

Did you send your family away before the epidemic, or when
it began?
I sent them North for the summer; my wife went North in May 1900.

list.item:
Q. #83 You remember the story in Kelly's book where Reed said,
“Gentlemen, I salute you”? As you know, it never happened.

item.p:
ANSWER I am quite sure it never happened. There was nothing dramatic
about Reed. Son Wihammia was awe it did.

Dr. Hench: When I told Mrs. Reed and General Lawrence Reed that story
was not true, General Reed was rather sorry to hear it. Knowing his
father as he did, he thought he might have said something like that, but
not so dramatic.

General Kean: He may have said it; in the pictures of it he is saluting
without a cap.

list.item: Q. #84: Can you tell me anything more about Lazear's funeral?

ANSWER: It was held about eleven o'clock in the morning the day
after he died. There were only about 40 or 50 at the funeral- perhaps
10 or 12 officers on horseback, hospital corpsmen, six or eight nurses
and perhaps twenty enlisted men. It is my recollection that they had
a band, but you told me that General Truby tells otherwise. The
Episcopal commitment service was used, I believe.
Q. #85: Who was Madame Abreu's husband?

item.p:
ANSWER: She did not have any husband when I was around there. She
had a number of animals in her beautiful plantation “Las Delicious”.
Agramonte said that she had a chimpanzee that was very gentle and in-
telligent and very well trained; she very often had him as a companion
to dinner. It was quite a well known animal. Agramonte said that he
got him and took him down to the ward and that the chimpanzee was im-
mune to yellow fever.
Dr. Hench: Why did the monkey not get yellow fever?

General Kean: The monkey had lived in Cuba for quite a while, but he
may still have been immune. African monkeys are immune, because that
is the home of the disease, and they have developed a racial immunity.
Dr. Hench: How did Agramonte happen to ask her for the animal?

General Kean: She was the only one who had a chimpanzee; she was a very
friendly person in good standing, and she would be apt to do what she
wanted.

list.item: Q. #86: Where did Walter Reed die?

item.p: ANSWER: Walter Reed died in the hospital at Washington Barracks.
Dr. HencH Do you remember what room he died in?

Gen. Kean: It was on the second floor and on the left hand side of the
hall, but it was not the front room; the next room to the front. I think

list.item:
Q #87: Do you have any recollection of where the prison was in
Pinar del Rio where the soldersoldier was who got yellow fever and died?
ANSWER: No I have not.
Q. #88 Do you think that prison is still there?

item.p: Answer: They were pretty substantial buildings - I guess so.
Dr. Hench: Is that garrison still there?
Gen. Kean: It might be.The buildings probably are-

list.item:
Q. #88: Did Reed tell you anything personally about the experience at
Pinar del Rio?

ANSWER: That was very familiar to me. I think that Reed did tell
me. Reed used to laugh at me a great deal about Pinar del Rio. I was
sent there to dispose of military property about September 1900 after I
came back from my sick leave. The army people were full of this idea of
fomites and they did not want to buy from the commissary at Pinar del
Rio, and I recommended that the commissary supplies be sold to the Cubans. The
Cubans were very glad to get most of the stuff. (They were mostly immune to Y F).
Q. #89 What did you have to do with the disposal?

item.p:
ANSWER: I just made a recommendation to the Commanding General. I
went up to Pinar del Rio and spent several days and recommended that it
be taken in a storehouse and then disposed of. Walter Reed asked me,
"Kean, what did you do with that stuff, what did you burn up and what did
you sell to the Cubans. He was full of fun. This was many months later
after I had joined him in Washington.

Reed never went back to Cuba after early Spring of 1901. He came
out of Cuba Feb. 9, 1901, and never went back.

list.item:
Q. #90: In Reed's letter of June 5, 1901 he says, “I do not share
your hopefulness concerning finding some immunizing method”. Apparently
- 12 -
you had some ideas about immunity that you expressed to Reed.

ANSWER: I had rather vague general ideas; I thought that when you
were working on a disease like that you should find some way to give
people immunization. I had nothing special in mind.

QUESTION #91: In one of General Truby's letters to you in 1914, he
chided slightly about Agramonte.

ANSWER: Truby had some prejudice against Agramonte. I pre-
ferred Agramonte to Carroll, and he preferred Carroll to Agramonte. We
had seen different aspects of the work, and I found he was a straight
forward and reliable man. Carroll did a number of improper things, and
ifthought Reed robbed him of his credit in the matter, Reed had made Carroll.
QUESTION #92: In one of your letters to me you talked about Noguchi.

item.p:
ANSWER: He went over to Africa to the experimental station, and he
took big chances there. He would never have gone there except for the
experiments.

Hench: Someone remarked to me once they thought Noguchi committed
suicide. (I think we did. WBC)
or was just stupid.

General Kean: I see no reason that Noguchi committed suicide; it is
perfectly possible, but I see no reason.

list.item:
QUESTION #93: When you went with Reed to see General Wood on October
12 and suggested to Reed to use Spanish volunteers, did Reed tell you
that he had already planned to use humans - not necessarily Spanish -
but humans?

item.p:
ANSWER: I do not remember that matter. It was perfectly well assumed
by him and me that he was going to have experiments on humans.

(Confidential): One time when I was in Washington - I do not quite re-
member when - but it was while the experiments were going on, I began
to talk over with Mrs. Reed her husband's work, and she was very much
shocked at the idea of inoculating human beings. She thought it was
terrible, and I said “I did not think so at all, and I am surprised that
you should think so; it has turned out wonderfully, and is a great piece
of work, and will save many lives.” Then she shut up.

list.item:
QUESTION #94: Do you remember of your own knowledge anything about
Reed's reaction to Carter's paper?

item.p:
ANSWER: He told me that he had read this paper with interest,
and that Carter had shown that if a man is exposed to yellow fever in
New Orleans and came up to his home in a town in Mississippi and had
yellow fever, a secondary case of yellow fever would not occur for three
weeks, but after that a case from that man would occur in a week, and he
wanted to know why it was it took three weeks for the first man to pass
on the infection, and afterwards it took only one week. I said I do not
know why. He said “don't you see that the difference was caused by the
development of the infection in an insect. We have biting insects, but
in Virginia we have the mosquito in lower Virginia, and the bedbug and
the flea, but the bedbug and the flea have never been accused of carrying
yellow fever, but the mosquitoes are down in Tidewater, and that is where
the yellow fever appears; it does not go up in the Piedmont country.”

The following is confidential, meaning that General Kean doesn't
wish to be quoted directly, but is willing for me to use the material
without quoting him:

list.item:
#94: You have read the abstracts from General Sternberg's Biography in
- 14 -
which Mrs. Sternberg includes quotations from General Sternberg's
remarks of Agramonte to the effect that when the Yellow Fever Board
was formed, Sternberg in the very first conversation with Reed out-
lined to Reed in a very precise fashion the various steps to be carried
out in the investigation of yellow fever. Dr. Howard in his book ex-
presses another attitude, and states that he first believed the same
thing, but later was corrected by Reed, and therefore Howard in a later
paper corrected the impression, and stated that Reed was the one who
had all the ideas to study out. How much do you think Sternberg told
Reed in the original instructions?

ANSWER: It should be divided into the general instructions about the
cause of yellow fever, and a particular one about an animal host. I
have no doubt that Sternberg had been quite minute along the line of
work of which he was so familiar, but I do not believe that he suggested
the transmission by the mosquito.
Q. #95: Will you repeat what Reed told you and when.

item.p:
ANSWER: I think in the summer of 1902 Reed told me that he asked General Sternberg
whether he should investigate the mosquito theory of Finlay and General
Sternberg replied “You can do so if you wish, but I think you will be
wasting your time”.
Dr. Hench: Do you remember this conversation distinctly?

Gen. Kean: I do. There are very few conversations from which I can
repeat words, but I can do it in that statement of Reed's. Reed thought
Sternberg was getting over on his territory.

list.item:
Q. #96: Was it understood by many of you that Sternberg was trying
to bring too much credit to himself?

Answer: No I do not think that many people thought about it, or
it; it was just along a margin of credit, and of course I was a champion
15 -
of Reed's and I shared his feelings. There was no particular discussion
among the various medical officers.

Q. #97: On page 277 of Sternberg's Biography, Sternberg is quoted as
follows: “The written instructions given by me to this selective Board
were as follows”; did you ever know that Sternberg gave Reed written
instructions? I have never been able to find any written instructions
in the National Archives after considerable search. On page 278 “In
addition to these written instructions I talked freely with Major Reed
etc.” Isn't it peculiar that this is the only reference we can find
to any written instructions. Is it possible that this is a false memory
on his part?
ANSWER: I think it must be a slip of memory.

Q.#98: What is your general reaction in this whole matter of the
controversy between Reed and Sternberg - Sternberg, his wife and others
saying so explicitly that Sternberg gave written instructions?

Answer: It is a perfectly natural thing for him to do to give him
instructions, and as Sternberg had devoted a great part of his life in
work on yellow fever, it is perfectly natural that he would be explicit.
The only question is that he made any suggestion regarding investiga-
tion of the mosquito theory, and I think there is no evidence he did,
and Reed denies explicitly that he did.

Q. #99: Why did Agramonte write so precisely and give such specific
credit to Sternberg?

item.p: Answer: Agramonte knew nothing more than I do.

Dr. Hench: Remember General, that in retrospect everybody calls this
the Yellow Fever Commission; as a matter of fact the original orders do
not even mention yellow fever. It was a Commission to study various
contagious diseases. Sternberg says in his discussion here that they
- 16 -
were to study various diseases, and it was only because the commission
took yellow fever and became famous that the Board was called the Yellow
Fever Board. Who decided that the Board was to work on yellow fever?
From what I can see they were to investigate a number of things, and it
was up to Walter Reed what to study first. If that is the case I do
not see that we have any concrete evidence that Sternberg emphasized
yellow fever any more than any other diseases.

Gen. Kean: You must remember that Kober was a great admirer of Stern-
berg's and the book about him was written by his wife and Kober.

list.item:
Q. 100: You remember that Howard stated in his book that Reed and
Lazear and Carroll had visited him (Howard) to learn about mosquitoes
before they went down to Cuba.

item.p:
Gen. Kean: It is my opinion that Lazear did not know Reed. I do not
think there was any evidence that Lazear knew Reed before he went to
Cuba.

Dr. Hench: I agree with you; it says that in his book, but the other
Howard
day when I visited him he decided he had been wrong, and he told me
that Lazear had come alone several times from Baltimore.
Gen. Kean: I think he is right about that.

list.item:
Q. #101: When did you first hear the suggestion that Lazear had in-
surance and did not want to risk it?

ANSWER: Very soon after his death. I think I got that impression
from Reed.

Q. #102: Who started the story about Lazear's insurance? Reed did
not arrive in Cuba until about a week after Lazear's death. Therefore
it would seem to me that Reed did not start the insurance story, but
somebody must have suggested it to Reed.
ANSWER: This is my impression, but I am not positive.

QUESTION #103: Referring to Page 6 of our interview of January 6,
1944, what were the quarantine regulations referred to?

ANSWER: The orders of the Post Commander. They were somewhat
different in different places, but in general terms no one should go
into an infected town, or to any source of yellow fever infection.
They were forbidden to go to Havana and forbidden to go to Marianao.
Reed commanded his men not to go to Havana or Marianao. I never saw
any orders that no one should bring mosquitoes in. The Post Commander
has every authority.
Q. #104: Where are the heights of Cabaña?

ANSWER: They would be south of Morro Castle, east of Havana Harbor.
Cabaña was the name of the fortress, but the region was behind it

Q. 105: Quite a number of Spanish immigrants arrived, how many be-
came infected?

ANSWER: The immigrants were numbered in dozenshundreds, but how many got
yellow fever I do not know. A considerable number were infected in Havana.
Records are given in reports of Dr. Finlay and Gorgas.

Q. 106: In our interview of May 8, 1941, page 7 you say “Reed
probably would have been arrested”. If Reed was there under orders of
the Surgeon General to do a job how could he possibly be arrested by a
local commanding officer?

ANSWER: If he broke the orders of the Post Commander at a post
there is not an order from the Surgeon General to protect him. The
Post Commander has great authority. It was a favor to Reed to be allowed
to be on the post.

Q. 107: Did Reed ask the Commanding Officer to be allowed to live
on the post and do this work?

ANSWER: I do not think Reed asked the Commanding Officer, but I do
not know. It would certainly have been the proper thing for him to call
on the Commanding Officer. Whether he did or not, I do not know. I
domnot know what happened theren because I was sick.

Dr. Hench: The whole thing was rather secret, and I think they regarded
it more or less a secret, and kept it even from the Commanding Officer.

General Kean: Yes, it was a great deal of a secret - Reed was very
cautious about everything relating to these infections. He did not want
any trouble made about it.

QUESTION #108: Let me ask you again. When Reed got back in Cuba early
in October and you met him when you were on the inspection trip at Ma-
tanzas, did Reed know before you saw him that Lazear had died?

ANSWER: I do not think so. So far as I know, Reed left Washington
or New York the day Lazear died. Reed left in the afternoon and Lazear
died at night. I told him that Lazear had died; he felt very sad about
it and spoke very feelingly; he expressed his regret. I went on board
the boat at Matanzas and met Reed.
QUESTION #109: Who else went with you to see Reed?

ANSWER: I think I went downto Matanzas with Havard, but I do not think he went
out on the boat.

QUESTION #110: Do you remember any of the conversation when Reed ex-
pressed to you his indignation that Carroll having offered himself for
the experiment should then break quarantine and go to Havana?

ANSWER: I do not remember the specific details of the conversation
but he talked to me privately about it, and later when Reed and I went
to see General Wood, Reed was rather embarrassed to have to admit not
one of the three cases was controlled perfectly.

QUESTION #111: Tell me the story about Reed offering XY money if he
would admit he broke quarantine.

ANSWER: Reed sent for XY and had a long talk with him, and Reed said
he offered him a gold piece that he had in his pocket if he would admit
he left the post, and XY stated he would like to have it, but he had to
state the fact that he had not left the post. Reed told me this, and
he said he would like to have the money, but it was a fact that he had
not left the post.

QUESTION #112: What was Reed's relationship with Carroll. Was it a
close friendship, or one of professional association?

ANSWER: I do no think there was any intimacy, but I think that Reed
liked Carroll and took a great interest in him, and done a great deal to
improve Carroll's aspirations and to improve himself.star* I do not think
there was any affectionate feeling. Lazear was a much superior man to
Carroll, but Lazear was reserved.
QUESTION #113: Was Carroll jumped a rank when he was promoted?

ANSWER: He was first contract surgeon with the relative rank of
Lieutenant in the Volunteers, which was the same relative rank for
Volunteers or Regulars. The he was a Lieutenant in the Regular Army and
by a special act of Congress was promoted to Major In the Regular Corps.
